11 times square marking the completion
of a 30-year project to revitalize the
ones blighted neighborhood in the 70s
and 80s Times Square was a pretty dicey
place forty-second Street was a zoo of
the most highly articulated different
kind of weirdos imaginable this was a
place for drug dealers there were sex
shops and peep shows and runaway kids is
called the deuce in 1980 the stateless
city said ok we're going to revitalize
Times Square and promptly things moved
very slowly originally they wanted to
put for office towers right smack in the
middle of Times Square that resembled
really suburban office towers we didn't
want to do that we wanted to make it
into the chaotic popular overcrowded
24-7 layered place that it has been in
its heyday and we were allowed to redo
the plan but we had to find real tenants
so we sent out letters to 800 big
entertainment company small
entertainment companies not-for-profits
and then we found Disney Disney was very
important because it became sort of the
flypaper for other entertainment
companies that would be interested in
Times Square it was a hard decision for
them because the street was ripped still
really sleazy by the time they agreed to
sign up but we had the best Broadway

Theatre and they signed on it's Disney
that brought madame tussaud's that

I like the fact that it's a big

Fridays lens blog profiles a
photographer who has spent the last five
years documenting the lives of gay
lesbian and transgender Americans my
name is Molly Landreth I'm 32 years old
and I am a photographer and multimedia
artist in CL embodiment a portrait of
queer life in America is a project that
I've been working on since 2005 this
photograph is called meg and Renee
Seattle Washington with it I really
wanted to capture this sweet tender
moment sort of like they get iconic
lovers in a car I'm really interested in
looking at people who identify as queer
in one way or another gay lesbian
transgender bisexual but also
intersecting that with race class
religion geography I came out of a total
personal need to see these lives and
hear these stories that seemed invisible
to me this one is Joe and Connie in st.
Paul Minnesota I told Joe just look at
her like you love her and I heard her
mutter that's the way I always look at
her this is a photograph of diamond
dynasty in st. Louis Missouri diamond
talks a lot about the violence that
she's experienced in the racism that
she's experienced so the fact that she
decided to choose this sort of
bullet-ridden shirt to be photographed
in is I thought it was pretty incredible
seems like everybody asks about this one
it's called chickadee and her family
here she is with her husband and two
children and then their mutual live-in
lover both of the women are like
feminist burlesque dancers so if this
isn't queer I don't know what else its
last year i collaborated with video
artist Amelia Toby who
currently living in New York from Sydney
Australia together we're creating about
26 short videos along with a whole lot
of new photographs and a really
interactive website that will be
launched the spring I want an archive of
queer life in America to exist and I
want images that I can relate to and
then I'm proud of to exist in this world
